Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Oligomers Derived from Emerging Nitroaromatic Pollutants in Anaerobic Environments: Mechanisms, Fate and Toxicity

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510698
Field

Numerous organic compounds that are used as explosives, pesticides, and pharmaceuticals involve the use of nitrogen substitute aromatic compounds. These compounds can enter into aquatic environments after use in agriculture and firing ranges or from industrial and household discharges. It is known that these compounds may form polymers in waters reactive in the presence of oxygen. The current paradigm is that the polymerization of these compounds only occurs under conditions with oxygen dissolved in the aqueous waters. However, preliminary evidence has shown coupling reactions can also occur in the absence of oxygen which may have important implications to their toxicity in ground waters and other waters with low oxygen concentrations. The main focus of this project is to provide a mechanistic basis for the anaerobic coupling reactions between reactive intermediates derived from the microbial reduction of nitroaromatic pollutants.

In anaerobic environments, the nitroaromatic compounds will undergo reductive (bio)transformation to aromatic amines via nitroso- and hydroxylamine-intermediates. The research will explore whether certain taxonomic groups of anaerobic microorganisms with nitroreductase genes become enriched as a consequence of the bioreduction of nitroaromatic compounds. Next the project will test three hypothesized mechanisms of coupling. The first two involve nucleophilic attacks on nitrosobenzene intermediates by either aromatic hydroxylamines or amines, forming azoxy (Ar-N+(O-)=N-Ar) or azo bonds (Ar-N=N-Ar), respectively. The third hypothesis is the coupling of radicals formed from the oxidation of aromatic amines by metals. The extent of the coupling reactions is expected to depend on the nitroaromatic structure. Coupling of compounds with just one nitro group may be limited to dimers; whereas, structures with multiple nitro groups can continue coupling to form large polymers. Extensive coupling reactions are also expected with a continuous supply of nitroaromatic pollutants which would allow for a continuous production of reactive intermediates. Isotopically labeled model compounds (15N, 13C and 14C) will be used to help elucidate the structure of humic-like substances formed in the absence of O2. Preliminary data indicate that dimers have an increased toxicity compared to the original nitroaromatic compounds justifying a detailed evaluation of their microbial and aquatic toxicity in this project. The project will have impacts on risk assessment, green synthesis, high school STEM education, inclusion of minorities in the scientific and educational enterprises, and the long term goals of the research group. Azo dyes lend themselves nicely to STEM projects because concentration is visually observable.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF research project was a collaboration of the departments of chemical and environmental engineering; chemistry; and environmental science at the University of Arizona.

 Nitroaromatic compounds are an important class of emerging contaminants of concern. Nitroaromatics compounds are uncommon in the natural biosphere and they enter the environment through their use as explosives, pesticides, pharmaceuticals, solid fuels and fragrances. One explosive compound, 2,4-Dinitroanisole (DNAN), is a common ingredient used for insensitive munitions, which are rapidly replacing conventional explosives because they minimize unintended detonations. DNAN and other insensitive munitions are an important source of contamination issue at military practice firing ranges. Insensitive munitions seldom detonate completely, thus residues accumulate on the soil at firing ranges where they become a prolonged source of environmental contamination as they dissolve and leach during each rainfall/snowfall event.

 The overall aim of this project was to monitor, the fate and toxicity of DNAN and its analogues in the environment. The analogues are simplified model compounds related in structure to DNAN. Typically environmental contaminants are biodegraded or biotransformed to smaller simpler products but nitroaromatics undergo unique reactions which cause them to couple and form larger molecules of several aromatic rings (oligomers). The emphasis of this project was to study the formation of the oligomers, which is of tremendous intellectual merit, since these reactions have not been studied very well in the past.

 In the environment, nitroaromatic compounds are microbially reduced to aromatic amines if reducing conditions prevail (e.g. lack of oxygen). The project research revealed two mechanisms that lead to the formation of the oligomers. The first mechanism are substitution reactions that occur between the aromatic amines and transient reduction products known as “nitroso” intermediates as the nitro-groups are initially reduced. These substitution reactions result in the formation of azobenzenes or nitrosodiphenylamines, which have some heightened toxicity characteristics compared to the original nitroaromatic compounds. The second mechanism are substitution reactions which occur between aromatic amines (originating from the reductive biotramformation of nitroaromatics) and soil organic matter. The humus that makes up soil organic matter contains quinone groups that react with amines to rapidly form strong irreversible chemical bonds rendering the molecules inert. The reactions are also substitution reactions and they occur without any catalyst. The expectation is that the pollutants incorporated into the humus are non-toxic and can be considered as safe environmental end-points. 14C-labelling experiments have shown strong evidence that most of the 14C in DNAN during bioremediation becomes incorporated into non-extractable bound residue associated with the soil organic matter.

 From an engineering perspective, the research results provide clues for a novel approach to the bioremediation of nitroaromatic contaminants by favoring their rapid irreversible incorporation into soil organic matter. Armed with the knowledge that the irreversible incorporation is due to quinone groups, the bioremediation strategy proposed can be improved by favoring conditions, which improve levels of quinones in soil humus, or by just increasing the level of soil organic matter.

This research has led to professional development and educational outcomes. The project has generated multiple peer reviewed journal articles, several presentations at national and international conferences. The project proposal has supported two PhD students, one visiting scientist and two high school students. 

 


Last Modified: 11/17/2019
Modified by: Jim A Field
